current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To establish an Office of Rural Education Policy in the
		  Department of Education.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Health, Education, Labor,
			 and Pensions

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was read twice and referred to the

short-title.#text:
Office of Rural Education Policy
			 Act

text.#text:
This Act may be cited as
			 the
The

quote.#tail:
, but a recent report by the Rural School and Community Trust
			 refers to the
quote.#text:
[r]ural schools have unique challenges and
			 benefits

paucity of rural education research in the United
			 States

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the number of
			 students attending rural schools increased by more than 11 percent, from
			 10,500,000 to nearly 11,700,000, between the 2004–2005 and 2008–2009 school
			 years. The share of the Nation’s public school enrollment attending rural
			 schools increased from 21.6 percent to 23.8 percent. In school year 2008–2009,
			 these students attended 31,635 rural schools, nearly one-third of all schools
			 in the United States.

text.#text:
Rural education
			 is becoming an increasingly large and important part of the United States
			 public school system. According to the Digest of Education Statistics reported
			 annually by the

Despite the
			 overall growth of rural education, rural students represent a demographic
			 minority in all but 3 States, according to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the increase in rural enrollment between the 2004–2005
			 and 2008–2009 school years was disproportionally among students of color.
			 Enrollment of children of color in rural schools increased by 31 percent, and
			 the proportion of students enrolled in rural schools who are children of color
			 increased from 23.0 to 26.5 percent. More than one-third of rural students in
			 12 States are children of color, according to research by the Rural School and
			 Community Trust (Why Rural Matters 2009).

text.#text:
Rural education
			 is becoming increasingly diverse. According to the

Rural education
			 is varied and diverse across the Nation. In school year 2007–2008, the national
			 average rate of student poverty in rural school districts, as measured by the
			 rate of participation in federally subsidized meals programs, was 39.1 percent,
			 but ranged from 9.7 percent in Connecticut to 71.9 percent in New Mexico,
			 according to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
attempted to encourage and
			 support rural applicants by providing additional points for proposals to serve
			 at least 1 rural local educational agency. But according to research by the
			 Rural School and Community Trust (Taking Advantage, 2010), this

term.#tail:
mainly had the effect of inducing urban applicants to include
			 rural participation merely in order to gain additional scoring points for
			 primarily urban projects.

text.#text:
Even policy
			 measures intended to help rural schools can have unintended consequences. In
			 awarding competitive grants under the Investing in Innovation Fund program
			 under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 14007 of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009/s:14007

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
found that rural schools were 1½ times more likely to provide
			 students access for online distance learning than schools in cities. A
			 September 2004 study from the

reported that
			 rural school districts used distance learning for teacher training more often
			 than non-rural school districts.

text.#text:
Rural schools
			 generally utilize distance education more often for both students and teachers.
			 A fall 2008 survey of public schools by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
reports that base salaries of both the lowest
			 and highest paid teachers are lower in rural schools than any other community
			 type.

text.#text: The

The
			 purposes of this Act are—
to establish an

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
regarding the impact of proposed changes in law,
			 regulations, policies, rules, and budgets on rural schools and
			 communities.

text.#text:
to provide input
			 to the

header.#text:
Impact analyses
				of rules and regulations on rural schools

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
publishes a general notice of
				proposed rulemaking for any rule or regulation that may have a significant
				impact on State educational agencies or local educational agencies serving
				schools with a locale code of 32, 33, 41, 42, or 43, as determined by the

) shall prepare and make
				available for public comment an initial regulatory impact analysis. Such
				analysis shall describe the impact of the proposed rule or regulation on such
				State educational agencies and local educational agencies and shall set forth,
				with respect to such agencies, the matters required under

, to be set forth with respect to small entities. The
				initial regulatory impact analysis (or a summary) shall be published in the
				Federal Register at the time of the publication of general notice of proposed
				rulemaking for the rule or regulation.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 603 of title
				5, United States Code

text.#text: Whenever the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
promulgates a final version of a rule

) shall
				prepare a final regulatory impact analysis with respect to the final version of

, to be set
				forth with respect to small entities. The

shall make copies of the
				final regulatory impact analysis available to the public and shall publish, in

				obtain a copy of such analysis.
